title: Nikolay Yung
text:
Nikolay Viktorovich Yung (;  – ) was a career officer in the <a href="Imperial%20Russian%20Navy">Imperial Russian Navy</a>, noted for his participation in the <a href="Battle%20of%20Tsushima">Battle of Tsushima</a> in the <a href="Russo-Japanese%20War">Russo-Japanese War</a> as captain of the <a href="battleship">battleship</a> .
Biography.
Yung was from the local nobility of <a href="Tver%20Governorate">Tver Governorate</a>. In 1872 he entered the <a href="Sea%20Cadet%20Corps%20%28Russia%29">Sea Cadet Corp</a> and was accepted into the Imperial Russian Navy in 1873. He graduated from the Naval Academy in 1876 ranked 18th in his class.
During the <a href="Russo-Turkish%20War%20%281877-1878%29">Russo-Turkish War</a> Yung was assigned to the <a href="Danube%20River">Danube River</a> flotilla as a <a href="warrant%20officer">warrant officer</a> and commanded a small patrol boat. He was promoted to lieutenant on January 1, 1882, and served on the <a href="clipper%20ship">clipper ship</a> "Zhemchug" later that year followed by the clipper "Rogue" from 1882-1885.
Around 1879, Yung became involved with the revolutionary group "<a href="Narodnaya%20Volya">Narodnaya Volya</a>" and was considered one of its founding members at the naval base of <a href="Kronstadt">Kronstadt</a>. The group initially stood for a mix of <a href="democracy">democratic</a> and <a href="socialist">socialist</a> <a href="reform%20movement">reforms</a>, including a <a href="Constituent%20Assembly">Constituent Assembly</a> (for designing a <a href="Constitution">Constitution</a>); <a href="universal%20suffrage">universal suffrage</a>; <a href="freedom%20of%20speech">freedom of speech</a>, <a href="Mass%20media">press</a>, and <a href="Deliberative%20assembly">assembly</a>; a volunteer military; land reform; and national <a href="self-determination">self-determination</a>. However, it soon mutated into a <a href="terrorist%20organization">terrorist organization</a> and was responsible for the assassination of <a href="Tsar">Tsar</a> <a href="Alexander%20II%20of%20Russia">Alexander II</a> in 1881. Yung escaped arrest at the time as he was on the "Rogue" circumnavigating the globe and only returned to Russia in 1886. He was taken into custody on his return, but was soon released by a <a href="military%20tribunal">military tribunal</a> after he disavowed connections to the organization.
Yung was promoted to lieutenant commander on August 30, 1893. He briefly serviced as acting captain of the battleship <a href="Russian%20battleship%20Poltava%20%281894%29">"Poltava"</a> in 1894, and in 1897 was captain of the cruiser "Vestnik". From 1898, Yung served on the committee for testing of new warships and on the examination board for testing <a href="midshipmen">midshipmen</a> for the Sea Cadet Corps.
From September 20, 1902 through April 19, 1904, Yung was captain of the cruiser . After the start of the <a href="Russo-Japanese%20War">Russo-Japanese War</a>, he was reassigned to command the battleship "Oryol", as part of the Second Pacific Squadron, which sailed from the <a href="Baltic%20Sea">Baltic Sea</a> to relieve the <a href="Russian%20Pacific%20Fleet">Russian Pacific Fleet</a> trapped at <a href="Port%20Arthur%20naval%20base">Port Arthur</a> by the <a href="Imperial%20Japanese%20Navy">Imperial Japanese Navy</a>. The squadron engaged Japanese Admiral <a href="T%C5%8Dg%C5%8D%20Heihachir%C5%8D">Tōgō Heihachirō</a>’s <a href="Combined%20Fleet">Combined Fleet</a> at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Tsushima">Battle of Tsushima</a> on May 15, 1905. During the battle, "Oryol" took a tremendous beating from the Japanese ships, and Captain Yung was seriously wounded and unconscious at the surrender of the Russian fleet by Admiral <a href="Nikolai%20Nebogatov">Nikolai Nebogatov</a>. He died of his wounds the following day. In accordance with the wishes of his crew, the Japanese permitted a <a href="burial%20at%20sea">burial at sea</a> at .
